definitions.definition: a feeling that you get when something affects your body

examples.text: I had a sensation of falling, as if in a dream.
A wonderful sensation filled his body.
For a special taste sensation, try our gourmet coffee.
He felt a tingling sensation down his side.
I had a strange sensation in my leg.
Lisa felt a burning sensation in her eyes.
Most people enjoy the sensation of eating.
the sensation of sand between your toes
She felt a sinking sensation in the pit of her stomach.
He was overwhelmed by a sensation of fear.
Rossi described the sensation of plunging downhill at 130 mph.

definitions.definition: the ability to feel through your sense of touch

examples.text: She seemed to have lost all sensation in her arms.

definitions.definition: a general feeling or impression that is difficult to explain; an experience or a memory

examples.text: He had the eerie sensation of being watched.
When I arrived, I had the sensation that she had been expecting me.

definitions.definition: very great surprise, excitement, or interest among a lot of people; the person or the thing that causes this surprise

examples.text: News of his arrest **caused a sensation**.
The band became a sensation overnight.
Golf's latest teen sensation is Michelle Woo.
The series became a media sensation in the early 1950s.

wordOrigin: early 17th cent.: from medieval Latin sensatio(n-), from Latin sensus ‘faculty of feeling, thought, meaning’, from sentire ‘feel’.
